Nouse talks to Grounds and Ecology Manager

06/10/2022

â€œWe do our best to try and make the green infrastructure around the University as pleasant and aesthetic as we possibly can for people."

Image by Gordon Eastham

By Gracie Daw

Ahead of this edition, Nouse sat down with Gordon Eastham, Grounds and Ecology Manager, to discuss the campus grounds, the animals on campus and how students can interact with them. Gordon is responsible for the external environments at the University, which are â€œthe grounds, the shrub beds, the trees, the lakes and the sports fieldsâ€ or the â€œgreen infrastructureâ€ as well as managing a team of 25 people who manage the grounds.

With regards to the animals on campus, he noted that â€œthey are wild animalsâ€ which means that â€œwe canâ€™t interfere too muchâ€ especially because the law prevents them from doing so. â€œIf we have to make interventions, we have to obtain a licence to do itâ€.

The Grounds team are out on campus, all day every day and therefore can â€œroutinely spotâ€ something like an injured bird, â€œif we do have an injured bird, we will try and capture it and take it to say, the walled garden for it to convalesce or get better or they will take it to a vetâ€. He again emphasised that it is necessary to â€œbe very careful, because they are wild animals and they are protected under lawâ€.

He highlighted that the University of York has a Hedgehog Friendly Campus Gold Award as a result of their actions over the past years to attract hedgehogs. â€œThe main thing that we do is to try and create and maintain habitats which will encourage wildlife and encourage biodiversity generallyâ€. Examples of this are wildflower meadows, woodland blocks and the lake so that â€œwildlife has a home on campus, can find food on campus and can find shelter on campusâ€.

When speaking about the coexistence of students and environment on campus, Gordon highlighted that â€œstudents donâ€™t necessarily have to do anythingâ€. He asks that â€œpeople respect the environmentâ€, so be mindful of littering and do not take part in vandalism, something which is not tolerated.

He encouraged people toâ€œ get on and enjoy the grounds and the landscape in a passive, recreational kind of wayâ€. Before highlighting that â€œit is there for the enjoyment and wellbeing of all students and staff and other campus usersâ€.

The Grounds team buys a lot of duck corn which they bag up and can be purchased in retail outlets such as Nisa on campus. As a means to increase interaction, visitors can buy duck corn which can be fed to the wildfowl. â€œWe recognise that a lot of people come onto campus to do that ... feeding the ducks, geese and other birdsâ€.

He discouraged people from feeding birds bread, which isnâ€™t good for them or the environment if left to rot in the lake. People feeding the birds â€œactually helps us out as well because during the wintertime, when food is scarce, we do feed the wildfowl anyway to keep them going through the winter.â€

He wanted to remind people that wild animals can in fact be dangerous, such as squirrels which could bite if aggravated, and therefore discouraged visitors to campus from feeding animals other than the birds. He then added that visitors should â€œbear in mind that, because of the habitats we try to create on campus, there is a lot of natural food generated within those habitatsâ€.

He spoke about the â€œvariety of wildlife on campusâ€, before speaking enthusiastically about some peregrine falcons which have nested in the nesting box on the boiler house chimney. The box has been up for eight years, but â€œthis is the first year we have attracted some peregrine falcons to itâ€.

â€œWe get otters come coming into the lake from time to time, there are all kinds of thingsâ€ on campus, for example, â€œthere are several foxes on campus, itâ€™s not rare to see foxes on campusâ€. Recently, he rescued a brown long-eared bat from the Computer Science department.

â€œWeâ€™ve had barn owls, we have picked up deer on trail cameras and hedgehogs all the time.â€ He also spoke about the â€œdifferent species of birds: sparrow hawks, little spring plovers, pochard, little egretâ€.

He talked about some more unusual animals such as â€œwater shrew which have been recorded on campus, the dingy skipper butterfly, a Cettiâ€™s warbler which caused quite a stir among local bird watchersâ€. Currently, there is an ecological survey going on across campus â€œso that we can benchmark the range of biodiversity we do have on campusâ€.

Nouse reached out to our Instagram followers for questions for Gordon, and many were about the duck, Long Boi. Gordon started by answering these by saying that â€œI can understand why people get so exercised about himâ€ but that â€œI know nothing about Long Boi, I know he is an Indian runner duck and I know that somebody deposited him on campus at some point, but other than that I know nothing about him.â€

He then noted that despite Long Boiâ€™s fan base â€œhe canâ€™t get excited about himâ€ and that â€œI would be much more excited about the peregrine falcons turning upâ€.

He highlighted that Long Boi â€œis a duck out of placeâ€ and that â€œhe shouldnâ€™t be hereâ€. The University campus is not the best environment for him given that he cannot fly, meaning he is vulnerable to predation â€“ if he cannot get out onto the water quickly enough, he could fall victim to a fox attack. Gordon said that â€œhe should be on a farm somewhereâ€ instead.

One readerâ€™s question was about the impact of the heatwave and more likely hot weather on the ducks and campus more broadly. Gordon answered, saying that â€œwater levels will drop in the lake and probably there will be less oxygen in the water column, trees will struggle because they canâ€™t find enough moisture which will mean that they either physically start to die, or they drop their leaves much earlier.â€

The impacts of climate change means that the Grounds team are considering which trees and shrubs they plant to begin with. Furthermore â€œwildlife will struggle to find waterâ€. However, the two lakes on campus mean that the University is able to support those animals better. The Grounds team have also â€œfabricated and installed about 20 wildlife water stations around campusâ€ which should help all wildlife find water. In the future, it is expected that â€œspecies will changeâ€, for example species often found in the south may start to move north which is something â€œwe will just have to adapt toâ€

.With regard to the floods which regularly happen in the centre of York, Gordon noted that the campus lakes are highly unlikely to flood because of their construction meaning that the water level â€œmay rise a few inchesâ€ but that would be all unless the UK sees an unprecedented level of rain similar â€œto what we have seen in Pakistan, letâ€™s hope we never get anything like thatâ€.

He finally added â€œI would encourage anybody to read our ecological management plan and our landscape management plan which will tell you about us and what we doâ€. He then added â€œwe do our best to try and make the green infrastructure around the University as pleasant and aesthetic as we possibly can for people."
